taskGroup.name: Controlling what you view
taskGroup.intro: This NoPrint tutorial is going to get you started with some of the analysis functionality within Debrief.
taskGroup.onCompletion: So now you know how to go beyond merely formatting data, you're able to temporally navigate through an encounter, and produce plots of data

task.name: Using the Outline View
task.intro: Firstly, you'll be using the Outline View to control how much data is visible on the plot.
task.onCompletion: Now you're a master of manipulating data, a skill essential both to data analysis and the collation of information for transfer to further presentation via Word or PowerPoint

task.name: Primary and Secondary Tracks
task.intro: Debrief has a special place in its heart for vessel tracks, and provides capabilities to allow you to focus your attention on one or more tracks.
task.onCompletion: So, you now understand Primary and Secondary tracks. You're practically an analyst!

task.name: Controlling time
task.intro: Next we'll delve deeper in the temporal (time) control of track data - including different ways to display moving vessel tracks.
task.onCompletion: The Time Controller is a very capable panel that provides a wide range of functionality. You've now got an idea how to control it.

task.name: Producing data plots
task.intro: Debrief has lots of embedded functionality that deals with the relationship between two tracks: ranges, bearings, range and bearing rates ... You can access some of this computational ability by asking Debrief to produce plots of your data. You'll learn how in this cheat sheet.
task.onCompletion: And that's all for using Debrief for analysis. If you're from an organisation that conducts TMA analysis based on sensor data (or you've a general yearning to learn) why not go back to the Welcome page (using the Restore Welcome link at the top of this view and try the Debrief support for single sided reconstruction tutorial.
